quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to select users from NY and CA:
[!raw!]
SELECT * {0} users
{1} state = 'NY'
{2} state = 'CA'
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]The IN Operator[/h1]

The [b]IN [/b]operator is used when you want to compare a column with more than one value. 

For example, you might need to select all customers from New York, Los Angeles, and Chicago.
With the [b]OR [/b]condition, your SQL would look like this: [code format="sql"]SELECT * FROM customers 
WHERE City = 'New York'[b]
OR[/b] City = 'Los Angeles'
[b]OR[/b] City = 'Chicago';[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [img id="2816" width="100%"]

quizzes.question:
Select customers from NY, CA, or NC, using the IN statement.
[!raw!]
SELECT name, state 
{0} customers 
WHERE state IN {1};
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]The IN Operator [/h1]

You can achieve the same result with a single IN condition, instead of the multiple [b]OR[/b] conditions: [code format="sql"]SELECT * FROM customers 
WHERE City [b]IN ('New York', 'Los Angeles', 'Chicago')[/b];[/code]
This would also produce the same result: [img id="2816" width="100%"]
[note]Note the use of  [b]parentheses [/b]in the syntax.[/note]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the missing keywords to exclude customers from the states CA, NY.
[!raw!]
SELECT name, state 
FROM customers
WHERE state {0} ('CA', 'NY');
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]The NOT IN Operator[/h1]

The [b]NOT IN[/b] operator allows you to exclude a list of specific values from the result set. 

If we add the [b]NOT [/b]keyword before [b]IN [/b]in our previous query, customers living in those cities will be excluded:[code format="sql"]SELECT * FROM customers 
WHERE City [b]NOT IN[/b] ('New York', 'Los Angeles', 'Chicago');[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [img id="2817" width="100%"]
